Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Rubber Band Ligation and Hemorrhoidectomy for Grade III Hemorrhoids

Trial_Design.evidence: This multicenter, open-label, parallel-group, randomised controlled noninferiority trial was conducted across 10 hospitals in the Netherlands.

Participants.evidence: Adults with symptomatic grade III hemorrhoids were eligible. Exclusion criteria included prior rectal/anal surgery and medical unfitness.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised 1:1 to RBL or hemorrhoidectomy.

Objective.evidence: This trial compares the effectiveness of rubber band ligation (RBL) and hemorrhoidectomy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcomes were 12-month health-related quality of life (HR-QoL) and recurrence rate.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was web-based with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Eighty-seven patients were randomised (47 RBL, 40 hemorrhoidectomy) from October 2019 to September 2022.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 46 RBL and 33 hemorrhoidectomy patients.

Result_Outcome.evidence: RBL was not noninferior to hemorrhoidectomy in HR-QoL (mean difference -0.045; 95% CI, -0.087 to -0.004). Recurrence was higher in the RBL group (48.8% vs 6.1%; absolute risk difference 43%, 95% CI, 25%-60%).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were comparable, with 6% in the RBL group and 12% in the hemorrhoidectomy group experiencing complications.
